countermeasure.name: Anonymize sensitive data in datasets
countermeasure.desc:
Anonymizing data is a crucial step in protecting sensitive information and minimizing the risk of exposing personal data within datasets analyzed by Amazon Athena. By implementing data anonymization, you ensure that personal data is obscured or de-identified, reducing the potential for unauthorized access and data breaches.

To effectively anonymize data in Amazon Athena, follow these guidelines:

  1. Understand Data Sensitivity and Compliance Requirements: Identify the types of sensitive data within your datasets and understand the compliance requirements that apply to your organization. This will help you determine the appropriate level of anonymization needed.
  2. Leverage AWS Lake Formation for Data Governance: Utilize AWS Lake Formation to manage and enforce fine-grained access controls on your datasets. Lake Formation allows you to create and enforce policies that help protect sensitive data. More details can be found in the Anonymize and manage data in your data lake with Amazon Athena and AWS Lake Formation blog post.
  3. Use Built-in Anonymization Functions: Amazon Athena provides built-in functions to help with data anonymization, such as masking, tokenization, and encryption. For instance, you can use SQL expressions to replace certain data fields with anonymized values. Refer to the AWS Athena Security Documentation to learn more about the available functions and how to use them securely.
  4. Implement Field-Level Encryption: Use field-level encryption to encrypt sensitive fields within your datasets. This ensures that even if unauthorized access occurs, the sensitive data remains protected. AWS KMS (Key Management Service) can be used to manage cryptographic keys securely.
  5. Regularly Audit and Monitor Data Access: Conduct regular audits and monitor access to your data. AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config can help you track and log access to your Amazon Athena queries and underlying data stores, providing visibility into user actions and potential security issues.

By following these steps and leveraging the capabilities of Amazon Athena and AWS Lake Formation, you can effectively anonymize your data, thereby enhancing the security and privacy of the information analyzed within your data lake.

For further reference, consult the official Amazon Athena Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption of Athena table data
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure data stored in Amazon S3 buckets used by AWS Athena is protected from unauthorized access, configuring encryption at rest is paramount. This involves enabling server-side encryption (SSE) for the relevant S3 buckets. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Navigate to the S3 Management Console in your AWS account.
  2. Select the bucket where Athena stores its data.
  3. Go to the "Properties" tab of the selected bucket.
  4. Locate the "Default encryption" section and click on "Edit."
  5. Choose your preferred encryption method:
    • SSE-S3: Server-Side Encryption with Amazon S3-Managed Keys.
    • SSE-KMS: Server-Side Encryption with AWS Key Management Service (KMS) Keys.
    • SSE-C: Server-Side Encryption with Customer-Provided Keys.
  6. Click "Save changes" to enable or update the encryption settings.

Enabling server-side encryption helps you comply with security standards and protects your sensitive data from unauthorized access. For more detailed instructions, refer to the official AWS documentation on encrypting data in Athena and the overarching security guidelines for Amazon S3 buckets available here.

countermeasure.name: Implement AWS Lake Formation to enforce strict access controls
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing and enforcing detailed access control policies using AWS Lake Formation can significantly enhance the security posture of your data lake environment. AWS Lake Formation provides fine-grained access controls over data stored in Amazon S3, enabling you to restrict access to datasets by granting permissions at the database, table, column, or row level. This ensures only authorized users can access specific datasets, thereby minimizing the risk of unauthorized data access.

To begin, ensure that AWS Lake Formation is set up and integrated with your existing AWS Athena environment. Follow these steps:

  1. Configure AWS Lake Formation: First, navigate to the AWS Lake Formation console. Here, register your Amazon S3 data lake storage resources by specifying the Amazon S3 locations where your data resides. Refer to the AWS Lake Formation Getting Started Guide for detailed instructions.
  2. Define Access Control Policies: Use Lake Formation permissions to grant database, table, and column-level access to specific IAM users or roles. For instance, a policy might restrict access to a table containing sensitive information such as PII (Personally Identifiable Information) to only specific roles. Detailed instructions on defining these policies can be found in the AWS Lake Formation Data Access Control documentation.
  3. Integrate with AWS Athena: Ensure that your AWS Athena queries are compliant with the access controls set in Lake Formation. When users run queries in Athena, Lake Formation credentials automatically enforce the defined permissions, thus controlling access to the datasets. Review the AWS Athena and Lake Formation Integration Guide for implementation details.
  4. Monitor and Audit Access: Regularly monitor and audit access to your datasets using AWS CloudTrail and AWS Lake Formation's audit capabilities. This helps in tracking user activities and ensuring compliance with your organization's security policies. For more details, refer to the Athena CloudTrail Logs documentation and the Lake Formation Auditing documentation.

By leveraging AWS Lake Formation to implement and enforce detailed access control policies, you effectively reduce the risk of unauthorized data access in your Amazon Athena queries, thereby strengthening your overall data security strategy.

countermeasure.name: Secure query result sets
countermeasure.desc:
Storing Query Results in Encrypted S3 Buckets and Restricting Access Using IAM and S3 Bucket Policies

A key measure to secure your AWS Athena query results involves storing them in encrypted Amazon S3 buckets and ensuring that access to these buckets is strictly controlled using IAM and S3 bucket policies. Follow the steps below to implement this control effectively:

Step 1: Create an Encrypted S3 Bucket

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Navigate to the Amazon S3 service.
  3. Create a new S3 bucket, or select an existing one where you want to store the query results.
  4. Ensure that server-side encryption (SSE) is enabled for the bucket. You can use either SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS.

Step 2: Set Up IAM Policies

IAM policies are essential to control which users and roles have permissions to access the S3 bucket and perform actions on it. Follow these steps:

  1. Navigate to the IAM service in the AWS Management Console.
  2. Define a policy that grants necessary permissions to access the specified S3 bucket. You can utilize managed polices or create a custom policy. An example policy could be:

{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "s3:*",
            "Resource": ["arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name", "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*"]
        }
    ]
}

Attach this policy to the respective IAM roles that need access.

Step 3: Configure S3 Bucket Policies

S3 bucket policies can be used to enforce security controls on a specific bucket. Steps to configure S3 bucket policies:

  1. Select the S3 bucket created in step 1.
  2. Go to the 'Permissions' tab.
  3. Add a bucket policy that restricts access based on IAM roles, specific IP ranges, or conditions, ensuring fine-grained control over who accesses your bucket. A sample policy might look like this:

{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Principal": {"AWS": "arn:aws:iam::account-id:role/RoleName"},
            "Action": "s3:GetObject",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*",
            "Condition": {
                "IpAddress": {"aws:SourceIp": "your-ip-range"}
            }
        }
    ]
}

By following these procedures, you ensure that your Athena query results are stored securely and that access to these results is tightly controlled. For more detailed information, please refer to the AWS Athena Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use CalledVia context keys
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS Athena service, it is crucial to limit requests to AWS Athena by configuring policies to include the aws:CalledVia global condition context key. This ensures requests are made only from authorized services.

Begin by identifying the services that are authorized to make requests to AWS Athena. These could be AWS Lambda functions, AWS Glue, or other AWS services in your environment.

Next, modify the IAM policies associated with your Athena-related roles to include the aws:CalledVia condition. This condition context key allows you to specify the services that are permitted to invoke Athena actions.

Heres a step-by-step guide to implement this:

  1. Identify the IAM roles and policies that need to be updated.
  2. Open the IAM Management Console.
  3. Navigate to the relevant policy you wish to update.
  4. Edit the policy to include the Condition block with the aws:CalledVia context key. 
    
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": "athena:*",
    "Resource": "*",
    "Condition": {
      "StringEquals": {
        "aws:CalledVia": [
          "lambda.amazonaws.com",
          "glue.amazonaws.com"
        ]
      }
    }
  }
}
  5. Apply and save the updated policy.

By including the aws:CalledVia condition context key, you significantly reduce the surface area for unauthorized access to Athena. This control ensures that only requests from specified AWS services, such as Lambda or Glue, are allowed to interact with Athena.

For further details and guidance, please refer to the official AWS Athena security documentation.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted table data
threat.desc:
General threat description
If data within Athena tables is not encrypted, it may be accessed by unauthorized parties, leading to potential data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, malicious insiders, or attackers exploiting misconfigurations or vulnerabilities in the AWS environment.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, potential data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and damage to organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an AWS account and finds unencrypted Athena tables containing sensitive data, which they can exfiltrate. A malicious insider with access to Athena tables abuses their permissions to access and share sensitive information without detection.

threat.name: Improper result set access
threat.desc:
General threat description
If result sets of Athena queries are not properly secured, they could be accessed by unauthorized users.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized personnel gaining access to improperly secured Athena query result sets through misconfigured access permissions.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, potential compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages misconfigured AWS permissions to access confidential data stored in Athena query results, exposing sensitive information to unauthorized entities.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper anonymization, sensitive data within datasets can be exposed to unauthorized individuals, leading to potential data breaches and privacy violations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and careless or untrained employees. Attack vectors range from direct access to the AWS Athena service without proper anonymization protocols to intercepting data in transit.
Impacts
Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive information, potential legal and compliance violations, loss of customer trust, and significant financial penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios
Scenario 1: An employee queries a dataset in AWS Athena that contains unmasked Personally Identifiable Information (PII). The data is inadvertently shared or accessed by an unauthorized party, leading to a data breach.
Scenario 2: An external attacker leverages a misconfigured access control policy to retrieve sensitive data from AWS Athena, which was not properly anonymized, and uses the data for malicious purposes.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without strict access controls, unauthorized users might gain access to sensitive data, leading to potential data theft or misuse.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external hackers exploiting loose access permissions, and users accidentally sharing access credentials.
Impacts
Loss of sensitive data, financial repercussions, damage to reputation, and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious insider with knowledge of the system gains unauthorized access to financial records. An external hacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to access proprietary business information. A user accidentally shares their access credentials with a phishing attacker, compromising customer data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access through intermediary services
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized or intermediary services interacting with AWS Athena can lead to data leaks or malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, insiders, or unauthorized third-party services exploiting misconfigurations or security gaps.
Impacts
Exposure of sensitive data, financial loss, compliance violations, and potential damage to the organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to AWS Athena credentials through a compromised third-party service and executes queries to exfiltrate sensitive information. Alternatively, an insider uses intermediary services to route unauthorized requests, causing data exposure or unauthorized data modification.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Consider client-side encryption
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend that you plan your encryption strategy before implementing your table in DynamoDB. If you store sensitive or confidential data in DynamoDB, consider including client-side encryption in your plan. This way you can encrypt data as close as possible to its origin, and ensure its protection throughout its lifecycle. Encrypting your sensitive data in transit and at rest helps ensure that your plaintext data isnt available to any third party.

The AWS Database Encryption SDK for DynamoDB is a software library that helps you protect your table data before you send it to DynamoDB. It encrypts, signs, verifies, and decrypts your DynamoDB table items. You control which attributes are encrypted and signed.

countermeasure.name: Monitor DynamoDB operations using CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
CloudTrail can monitor both control plane events and data plane events. Control plane operations let you create and manage DynamoDB tables. They also let you work with indexes, streams, and other objects that are dependent on tables. Data plane operations let you perform create, read, update, and delete (also called CRUD) actions on data in a table. Some data plane operations also let you read data from a secondary index. To enable logging of data plane events in CloudTrail, you'll need to enable logging of data plane API activity in CloudTrail. See Logging data events for trails for more information.

When activity occurs in DynamoDB, that activity is recorded in a CloudTrail event along with other AWS service events in the event history. For more information, see Logging DynamoDB Operations by Using AWS CloudTrail. You can view, search, and download recent events in your AWS account. For more information, see Viewing Events with CloudTrail Event History in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

For an ongoing record of events in your AWS account, including events for DynamoDB, create a trail. A trail enables CloudTrail to deliver log files to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket. By default, when you create a trail on the console, the trail applies to all AWS Regions. The trail logs events from all Regions in the AWS partition and delivers the log files to the S3 bucket that you specify. Additionally, you can configure other AWS services to further analyze and act upon the event data collected in CloudTrail logs.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Config to monitor configuration changes and ensure compliance with security policies
countermeasure.desc:
Using AWS Config, you can continuously monitor and record configuration changes of your AWS resources. You can also use AWS Config to inventory your AWS resources. When a change from a previous state is detected, an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification can be delivered for you to review and take action. Follow the guidance in Setting Up AWS Config with the Console, ensuring that DynamoDB resource types are included.

You can configure AWS Config to stream configuration changes and notifications to an Amazon SNS topic. For example, when a resource is updated, you can get a notification sent to your email, so that you can view the changes. You can also be notified when AWS Config evaluates your custom or managed rules against your resources.

For an example, see Notifications that AWS Config Sends to an Amazon SNS topic in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB's encryption at rest to secure data stored in tables, backups, and streams
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB encrypts at rest all user data stored in tables, indexes, streams, and backups using encryption keys stored in AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). This provides an additional layer of data protection by securing your data from unauthorized access to the underlying storage .

You can specify whether DynamoDB should use an AWS owned key (default encryption type), an AWS managed key, or a customer managed key to encrypt user data. For more information, see Amazon DynamoDB Encryption at Rest.

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB Streams to monitor data plane operations
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB is integrated with AWS Lambda so that you can create triggerspieces of code that automatically respond to events in DynamoDB Streams. With triggers, you can build applications that react to data modifications in DynamoDB tables.

If you enable DynamoDB Streams on a table, you can associate the stream Amazon Resource Name (ARN) with a Lambda function that you write. Immediately after an item in the table is modified, a new record appears in the table's stream. AWS Lambda polls the stream and invokes your Lambda function synchronously when it detects new stream records. The Lambda function can perform any actions that you specify, such as sending a notification or initiating a workflow.

For an example, see Tutorial: Using AWS Lambda with Amazon DynamoDB Streams. This example receives a DynamoDB event input, processes the messages that it contains, and writes some of the incoming event data to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM policy conditions for fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
When you grant permissions in DynamoDB, you can specify conditions that determine how a permissions policy takes effect. Implementing least privilege is key in reducing security risk and the impact that can result from errors or malicious intent.

You can specify conditions when granting permissions using an IAM policy. For example, you can do the following:

  • Grant permissions to allow users read-only access to certain items and attributes in a table or a secondary index.
  • Grant permissions to allow users write-only access to certain attributes in a table, based upon the identity of that user.

For more information, see Using IAM Policy Conditions for Fine-Grained Access Control.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Improperly configured IAM policies can lead to unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improperly configured IAM (Identity and Access Management) policies in AWS can result in unauthorized access to DynamoDB tables. These policies govern who can access what resources and with what permissions. Misconfigurations can accidentally grant excessive privileges, allowing unauthorized users to read, write, or delete data, thereby compromising the security of the DynamoDB service.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include internal users such as employees or administrators who might misconfigure policies either accidentally or intentionally. External attackers can exploit stolen AWS credentials or use social engineering techniques to gain access. Automation tools with misconfigured permissions can also inadvertently expose sensitive data.

Impacts

The impacts of this threat include data breaches where sensitive information is exposed, data integrity issues from unauthorized modifications, service disruptions due to unauthorized configuration changes, and potential non-compliance with regulatory requirements, leading to legal and financial repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator accidentally grants excessive permissions to a DynamoDB table, allowing unauthorized internal applications to modify data. A phishing attack leads to compromised AWS credentials, which are then used to exploit an overly permissive policy, resulting in a data breach. A malicious insider with policy management privileges misconfigures policies to gain access to sensitive data, leaking it to external parties. An automation script with broad IAM permissions inadvertently changes access controls, exposing data to unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556 - Modify Authentication Process

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data transmitted over the network can be intercepted by malicious actors
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data transmitted over a network can be intercepted by malicious actors using various techniques such as man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, or session hijacking. In the context of AWS DynamoDB, data in transit between clients and the database service may be vulnerable if not adequately protected. Intercepted data can lead to exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized access, and manipulation of data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include cybercriminals, hackers, or state-sponsored actors who intercept data using MitM attacks, deploying tools to capture network traffic, or exploiting vulnerabilities in network security protocols. These attackers may gain access through compromised network infrastructure, unsecured Wi-Fi networks, or by exploiting weak encryption standards.

Impacts

The interception of data in transit can result in data breaches, exposing sensitive information such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property. It can also lead to unauthorized data manipulation, where the integrity and authenticity of the data are compromised. Additionally, it may cause loss of trust, reputational damage, and potential legal consequences for failing to protect customer data.

Example Attack Scenarios

A hacker sets up a MitM attack on an unsecured Wi-Fi network, intercepting data transmitted between a client application and the DynamoDB service, capturing sensitive information like authentication tokens and customer data. An attacker uses packet sniffing tools on a compromised network to monitor and extract data being transferred in plaintext due to lack of encryption. A cybercriminal exploits a vulnerability in a network protocol to hijack an active session between a user and the DynamoDB service, gaining unauthorized access to modify and steal data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

threat.name: Without proper monitoring, security incidents can go undetected, leading to prolonged exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Without proper monitoring, security incidents involving AWS DynamoDB can go undetected, allowing malicious activities to persist and causing prolonged exposure to threats. Continuous monitoring is essential for detecting unauthorized access, suspicious activities, and potential security breaches in real-time. Lack of monitoring can result in delayed response to security incidents, increasing the risk of data compromise and operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated threats such as malware. Attack vectors can involve exploiting vulnerabilities, using stolen credentials, and performing unauthorized data access or modifications. Absence of monitoring tools and alerting mechanisms makes it easier for these threats to operate undetected over extended periods.

Impacts

Undetected security incidents can lead to severe impacts, including prolonged unauthorized access to sensitive data, extensive data breaches, significant financial losses, and reputational damage. Additionally, prolonged exposure increases the complexity and cost of incident response and recovery, while also potentially resulting in regulatory non-compliance and legal penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

An external attacker exploits a vulnerability to gain access to DynamoDB and exfiltrates sensitive data over several months without detection due to lack of monitoring. A malicious insider continuously accesses and manipulates confidential information in DynamoDB, undetected due to insufficient logging and alerting. Malware infects an application accessing DynamoDB, gradually exfiltrating data without triggering any alerts because of inadequate monitoring. Anomalous access patterns indicating a security breach go unnoticed due to the absence of real-time monitoring and analysis tools.

threat.name: Sensitive data stored in DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in AWS DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized access. This can occur due to misconfigurations, inadequate access controls, lack of encryption, or insufficient monitoring. Ensuring that sensitive information such as personal, financial, or proprietary data is protected is critical to maintaining data confidentiality and integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders with sufficient access privileges, external attackers exploiting misconfigured permissions or vulnerabilities, and automated scripts or applications with excessive access rights. Attack vectors can include exploiting weak or default configurations, leveraging compromised credentials, or taking advantage of unencrypted data storage.

Impacts

The exposure of sensitive data can lead to significant consequences such as identity theft, financial loss, damage to reputation, and legal penalties for non-compliance with data protection regulations. Organizations may face operational disruptions, loss of customer trust, and competitive disadvantages if proprietary information is leaked.

Example Attack Scenarios

An insider with administrative privileges accesses and exfiltrates sensitive customer data stored in DynamoDB for personal gain. An external attacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to gain unauthorized access to financial records stored in DynamoDB. A developer accidentally deploys an application with excessive permissions, allowing it to read and expose sensitive data. Lack of encryption at rest results in an attacker accessing unprotected sensitive information directly from the storage medium.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Configure proper data backup and recovery mechanisms for Firehose delivery streams
countermeasure.desc:
Objective: Ensure data resiliency, availability, and disaster recovery for Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose delivery streams by configuring appropriate data backup and recovery mechanisms.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Source Record Backup:

  • Configure your Firehose delivery streams to back up all source data to an Amazon S3 bucket. This backup can be for all data or only failed data, depending on your needs. For destinations other than Amazon S3 and Amazon Redshift, this setting indicates if you want to back up all source data or failed data only (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Configure S3 Backup Settings:

  • S3 Bucket: Choose or create an S3 bucket where the backup data will be stored.
  • S3 Prefix: Specify a prefix for the S3 bucket to organize the backup files logically.
  • Error Output Prefix: Define a prefix for storing failed records, making it easier to identify and manage error data (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Set Buffering Hints:

  • Adjust the buffering size (1-128 MiB) and buffering interval (60-900 seconds) to optimize data delivery and backup performance. These settings help balance the trade-off between latency and throughput, ensuring efficient data processing and storage (AWS Documentation).

Enable Compression and Encryption:

  • Compression: Use compression methods such as GZIP, Snappy, or Zip to reduce storage costs and improve transfer speeds. Note that not all compression methods are compatible with all destinations (e.g., Snappy is not available for Amazon Redshift) (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).
  • Encryption: Implement server-side encryption using AWS Key Management Service (SSE-KMS) to protect your data. You can choose to use the default S3 encryption or a customer-managed key for additional security (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Monitor and Log Errors:

  • Enable error logging in CloudWatch to capture detailed logs of any data delivery or processing errors. This practice is crucial for troubleshooting and ensuring data integrity during recovery processes (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Set Up Disaster Recovery:

  • Utilize the multi-AZ (Availability Zone) support and automatic migration features of AWS to ensure high availability and disaster recovery. Firehose automatically handles host degradations and AZ availability issues, ensuring continuous data flow without data loss (AWS Documentation).

Best Practices:

  • Regularly review and test your backup and recovery configurations to ensure they meet your organizational needs.
  • Implement IAM roles with the least privilege principle to manage access to your Firehose streams and S3 buckets, enhancing security.
  • Periodically audit your S3 bucket contents and lifecycle policies to manage storage costs and maintain data hygiene.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Kinesis Data Firehose Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable server-side encryption using AWS KMS for data stored in Firehose delivery streams
countermeasure.desc:
Objective: Secure data in transit and at rest within Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose delivery streams by enabling server-side encryption (SSE) using AWS Key Management Service (KMS).

Implementation Steps:

Create an AWS KMS Key:

  • If you do not already have a KMS key, create one through the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs. This key will be used to encrypt data in your Firehose delivery streams.
  • To create a KMS key, navigate to the KMS section in the AWS Management Console, choose Create Key, and follow the prompts to define key policies and permissions (AWS Documentation).

Configure Encryption in Firehose Delivery Stream:

  • When creating or updating a Firehose delivery stream, configure server-side encryption settings to use the KMS key.
  • During the creation process, in the Configure Settings step, under Advanced Settings, enable server-side encryption and select your KMS key from the list (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Specify the KMS Key in the Firehose Console:

  • In the Firehose console, go to the Create Delivery Stream wizard.
  • In the Set Destination section, find the encryption settings.
  • Enable encryption and choose the KMS key you created from the dropdown menu.
  • Save and continue with the setup (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Update Existing Streams with Encryption:

  • To enable encryption for existing delivery streams, use the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs.
  • In the Firehose console, select the delivery stream you wish to update, choose Edit, navigate to the encryption settings, and select your KMS key (AWS Documentation).

Verify Permissions:

  • Ensure that the Firehose delivery stream has the necessary IAM permissions to use the KMS key.
  • The IAM role associated with the Firehose stream must have the kms:Encrypt and kms:Decrypt permissions for the specified KMS key. This can be configured in the IAM policy associated with the role (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Monitor Encryption Metrics:

  • Use Amazon CloudWatch to monitor metrics related to encryption.
  • Track logs and metrics for any encryption-related errors or warnings to ensure continuous data protection (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Best Practices:

  • Regularly rotate your KMS keys to enhance security.
  • Apply least privilege principles when configuring IAM policies to restrict access to KMS keys.
  • Enable CloudTrail logging for all KMS key usage to maintain an audit trail of all encryption and decryption operations.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Kinesis Data Firehose Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Implement fine-grained access control to restrict permissions to specific Firehose actions using IAM policies
countermeasure.desc:
Objective: Enhance security by restricting access to specific Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose actions through fine-grained IAM policies.

Implementation Steps:

Identify Required Permissions:

  • Determine the specific actions that users and services need to perform on the Firehose delivery streams. Common actions include firehose:CreateDeliveryStream, firehose:PutRecord, firehose:PutRecordBatch, and firehose:DeleteDeliveryStream.
  • Refer to the AWS Kinesis Data Firehose API documentation for a complete list of actions and their descriptions (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Create Custom IAM Policies:

  • Define custom IAM policies that grant only the necessary permissions. Use the principle of least privilege to ensure that users and roles have only the permissions they need to perform their tasks.

Attach Policies to Users or Roles:

  • Attach the custom IAM policies to the appropriate users, groups, or roles. This ensures that only authorized entities can perform the specified actions on your Firehose delivery streams.
  • Example command to attach a policy to a role using AWS CLI:

aws iam attach-role-policy --role-name YourRoleName --policy-arn arn:aws:iam::aws:policy/YourCustomPolicy

Test the IAM Policies:

  • After creating and attaching the policies, test them to ensure they work as intended. Use AWS IAM Access Analyzer or AWS IAM Policy Simulator to validate that the policies restrict access appropriately.
  • Make adjustments as necessary based on the testing results to tighten or loosen permissions (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Monitor and Audit IAM Activities:

  • Enable AWS CloudTrail to log and monitor all IAM activities, including policy changes and access to Firehose delivery streams. This helps in auditing and identifying any unauthorized access attempts.
  • Set up AWS CloudWatch Alarms to notify administrators of any suspicious activity or policy changes (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Review and Update Policies Regularly:

  • Regularly review and update IAM policies to adapt to changes in user roles, job functions, and security requirements. Ensure that the policies remain aligned with the principle of least privilege.
  • Conduct periodic access reviews and audits to ensure compliance with organizational security standards and best practices (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Kinesis Data Firehose Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Regularly validate Firehose delivery stream configurations to meet security and operational requirements
countermeasure.desc:
Objective: Ensure that Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose delivery streams continuously comply with security policies and operational requirements through regular validation and auditing.

Implementation Steps:

Set Up Initial Configuration Review:

  • When creating a new Firehose delivery stream, document the initial configurations including data transformation settings, encryption methods, buffer sizes, and error logging settings. This serves as a baseline for future reviews (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Schedule Regular Reviews:

  • Establish a regular review cycle (e.g., monthly, quarterly) to validate Firehose configurations. This helps ensure that the delivery streams meet evolving security policies and operational requirements.

Automate Configuration Audits:

  • Use AWS Config to continuously monitor and record configurations of Firehose delivery streams. Set up AWS Config Rules to evaluate the compliance of these configurations with your organizational policies.
  • AWS Config can trigger AWS Lambda functions to remediate non-compliant resources automatically (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Monitor Key Metrics and Logs:

  • Use Amazon CloudWatch to monitor key metrics such as delivery failures, data ingestion rates, and buffer usage. Set up CloudWatch Alarms to notify administrators of any anomalies.
  • Enable detailed logging through Amazon CloudWatch Logs for deeper insights into the operation of Firehose delivery streams, including data transformation errors and delivery failures (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Conduct Manual Reviews:

  • Regularly perform manual reviews of Firehose configurations using the AWS Management Console or AWS CLI. Verify that settings such as buffer sizes, retry intervals, and compression methods align with current operational requirements and best practices (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).
  • Example AWS CLI command to describe a delivery stream:

aws firehose describe-delivery-stream --delivery-stream-name your-stream-name

Validate Security Configurations:

  • Ensure that encryption is enabled for all Firehose delivery streams, using AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for server-side encryption.
  • Verify that IAM policies attached to Firehose roles are following the principle of least privilege. Regularly audit IAM roles and policies to ensure they have the necessary permissions without over-provisioning (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Update Documentation and Training:

  • Maintain up-to-date documentation of Firehose configurations and validation processes. Ensure that the operations team is trained on the latest security practices and operational procedures for managing Firehose delivery streams.

Best Practices:

  • Use tagging to categorize and manage Firehose delivery streams based on their purpose, sensitivity, and compliance requirements.
  • Regularly review and update lifecycle policies for S3 buckets storing Firehose backup data to manage storage costs and compliance with data retention policies (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).
  • Implement versioning in S3 buckets to protect against accidental deletions or overwrites of backup data.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Kinesis Data Firehose Developer Guide.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Improper access controls can result in unauthorized users accessing, modifying, or deleting Kinesis Data Firehose resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access controls can result in unauthorized users accessing, modifying, or deleting Kinesis Data Firehose resources. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, compromised user accounts, or external attackers who exploit weak permission settings or misconfigurations in access control policies. 
Impacts
The primary impacts of this threat include data breaches, data loss or corruption, and unauthorized use of resources, which could compromise data integrity, confidentiality, and availability. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gaining access to an inadequately protected AWS IAM role could modify Firehose delivery streams, redirecting data to an unauthorized endpoint, or could delete data streams, causing significant data loss and service disruption.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data exposure due to inadequate encryption measures during transit or at rest
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data exposure due to inadequate encryption measures during transit or at rest.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cyber attackers can intercept data in transit through man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks or exploit unencrypted storage locations 
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, data breaches, loss of confidentiality, and potential regulatory fines 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts data being sent to AWS Kinesis Data Firehose through a MITM attack, or gains access to unencrypted data stored within the system, thus compromising sensitive information

threat.name: Misconfiguration of Firehose resources can lead to vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfiguration of Firehose resources can lead to vulnerabilities. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include insider threats, such as employees misconfiguring resources, or external attackers exploiting misconfigured Firehose resources. Attack vectors can involve leveraging weaknesses in configuration settings or gaining unauthorized access to the system. 
Impacts
The impacts can span data breaches, unauthorized data access, data loss, and regulatory non-compliance, potentially leading to significant financial and reputational damage. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An employee accidentally misconfigures the Firehose delivery stream to allow public access, which could be exploited by an attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data. Another scenario could involve incorrect IAM policies that give unauthorized users access to Kinesis streams, resulting in data leaks or data manipulation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Improper data backup and recovery configurations can lead to data loss
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper data backup and recovery configurations can lead to data loss. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include misconfigured settings, lack of adequate backup procedures, or neglecting to test recovery plans. Attack vectors encompass accidental deletion, data corruption, and unplanned outages. 
Impacts
The primary impact is potential data loss, which can result in operational downtime, financial losses, and damage to reputation. Additionally, it can affect compliance with data retention policies and regulations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An example scenario might involve an AWS Kinesis Data Firehose stream where backups are not regularly scheduled. In the event of an accidental deletion or corruption of the data stream, the recovery process fails due to improperly configured recovery settings, resulting in permanent data loss. Another scenario could involve a backup configuration that does not include the latest changes, leading to data discrepancies upon restoration.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS CloudTrail for Kinesis Data Streams
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure visibility and traceability of all actions within AWS Kinesis Data Streams, enable AWS CloudTrail to log all API calls. This practice helps detect unauthorized activities and provides a comprehensive audit trail for security reviews. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Enable CloudTrail:

  • Navigate to the AWS CloudTrail console.
  • Create a new trail or use an existing trail.
  • Ensure the trail applies to all regions to capture all API activity.

Configure Logging:

  • Specify an S3 bucket for log storage with proper access controls and encryption.
  • Optionally, enable log file validation for added security.

Set Up Monitoring and Alerts:

  • Use Amazon CloudWatch to set up metrics and alarms based on specific API activity patterns.
  • Configure CloudWatch Alarms to alert security personnel when suspicious or unusual API calls are detected.

Review and Analyze Logs:

  • Regularly review CloudTrail logs to identify and investigate unauthorized or suspicious API calls.
  • Use AWS CloudTrail Insights for automated analysis and detection of unusual activity.

reference.name: Logging Amazon Kinesis Data Streams API Calls with AWS CloudTrail

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

countermeasure.name: Enable server-side encryption for Kinesis Data Streams
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data at rest in AWS Kinesis Data Streams, enable server-side encryption (SSE) using AWS KMS-managed keys. This ensures that data is automatically encrypted before being written to the stream and decrypted when read. Follow these steps:

Enable Server-Side Encryption:

  • Navigate to the Kinesis Data Streams console.
  • Select the data stream you want to encrypt.
  • In the stream details, enable server-side encryption.
  • Choose an AWS KMS key to manage the encryption. You can use an AWS-managed key or a customer-managed key (CMK).

Verify Encryption Status:

  • Check the stream details to ensure that SSE is enabled and the correct KMS key is being used.
  • Verify that new data being ingested into the stream is encrypted.

Update IAM Policies:

  • Ensure that IAM roles and policies allow access to the KMS keys used for encryption and decryption.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail to log and monitor all access to KMS keys and Kinesis Data Streams.
  • Set up CloudWatch alarms for unusual access patterns or failures in encryption/decryption operations.

reference.name: Data Protection in Amazon Kinesis Data Streams

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unencrypted Data at Rest in AWS Kinesis Data Streams refers to the risk posed by storing data in Kinesis streams without encryption. This can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive information if someone gains access to the storage backend. Encrypting data at rest ensures that even if physical storage media is compromised, the data remains protected and inaccessible to unauthorized users.

Threat Agents:

  • External attackers gaining access to storage media.
  • Malicious insiders with access to storage backend.
  • Unauthorized users exploiting vulnerabilities to access stored data.

Attack Vectors:

  • Physical theft or compromise of storage media.
  • Exploitation of software vulnerabilities that allow access to unencrypted data.
  • Misconfigured access controls allowing unauthorized access to storage resources.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information stored in Kinesis Data Streams, leading to potential data leaks and compliance issues.
  • Data Integrity Issues: Potential alteration of data by unauthorized entities, leading to unreliable or corrupted data.
  • Compliance Violations: Storing unencrypted data may violate industry regulations and standards, leading to legal penalties and reputational damage.
  • Reputation Damage: Security incidents involving unencrypted data can erode customer trust and damage the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Physical Compromise: An external attacker gains physical access to AWS data centers or backup media. Without encryption, the attacker can read sensitive data directly from the storage devices.
  2. Insider Threat: A malicious insider with access to the storage infrastructure retrieves unencrypted data from Kinesis Data Streams and leaks it to external parties, causing a significant data breach.
  3. Exploitation of Misconfigurations: A developer accidentally misconfigures access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access unencrypted data in Kinesis Data Streams. Attackers exploit this vulnerability to extract sensitive information.

By implementing these strategies, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with unencrypted data at rest in AWS Kinesis Data Streams, ensuring the protection of sensitive information and compliance with security best practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

threat.name: Lack of API call monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Lack of API Call Monitoring in AWS Kinesis Data Streams refers to the absence of oversight and tracking of API calls made to the service. Without proper monitoring, unauthorized or malicious activities may go undetected, leading to potential security breaches, data loss, and operational disruptions. Continuous monitoring of API calls is crucial for detecting suspicious activities and ensuring compliance with security policies.

Threat Agents:

  • External attackers exploiting unmonitored API calls.
  • Malicious insiders performing unauthorized actions.
  • Compromised accounts used to execute unauthorized API calls.

Attack Vectors:

  • Unauthorized API calls using stolen or compromised credentials.
  • Insiders abusing their access rights to make unauthorized changes.
  • Automated scripts or bots making excessive or unauthorized API requests.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access and actions can lead to data breaches and leakage of sensitive information.
  • Service Disruption: Malicious API calls can disrupt the normal operation of Kinesis Data Streams, leading to downtime and loss of productivity.
  • Compliance Violations: Lack of monitoring can result in non-compliance with industry regulations and standards, attracting legal penalties.
  • Reputation Damage: Security incidents arising from unmonitored API calls can erode customer trust and damage the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Data Access: An attacker gains access to AWS credentials through a phishing attack. Without API call monitoring, the attacker makes unauthorized API calls to Kinesis Data Streams, exfiltrating sensitive data without detection.
  2. Insider Threat: A disgruntled employee uses their access rights to perform unauthorized API actions, such as deleting data streams or modifying configurations, causing significant operational disruptions.
  3. Automated Bot Attack: A botnet performs a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack by making excessive API requests to Kinesis Data Streams, overwhelming the service and causing a denial of service for legitimate users. Without monitoring, the attack goes undetected until service disruptions occur.

By implementing these mitigation strategies, organizations can ensure comprehensive monitoring of API calls to AWS Kinesis Data Streams, enhancing security and reducing the risk of unauthorized actions going undetected.

weakness.name: CWE-1047
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1047: Modules with Circular Dependencies The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

weakness.name: CWE-1193
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1193: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-312
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-312: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-416
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-416: Use After Free Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-672
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-672: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.

weakness.name: CWE-913
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-913: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code, or resources used by code such as variables and objects. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can directly influence these code resources in unexpected ways.

countermeasure.name: Apply permission boundaries to cap Lambda role and user privileges
countermeasure.desc:
Define a single IAM permission-boundary policy that represents the maximum set of actions a Lambda workload should ever performtypically the core lambda:*, CloudWatch Logs calls, and tightly scoped access to specific AWS resources. Attach that boundary to:

  • Every Lambda execution role (via the PermissionBoundary property in CloudFormation/Terraform).
  • All human or CI/CD principals that can create or update functions.

Because AWS evaluates the boundary before attached or inline policies, anything not explicitly allowed by the boundary is automatically deniedeven if someone tries to grant broader rights later.

quick implementation

  1. Author and publish the boundary
    1. {
       "Version":"2012-10-17",
       "Statement":[
         { "Effect":"Allow", "Action":[
             "lambda:*",
             "logs:CreateLogGroup", "logs:CreateLogStream", "logs:PutLogEvents"
           ], "Resource":"*" },
         { "Effect":"Deny", "Action":[ "iam:*", "organizations:*", "lambda:DeleteFunction" ], "Resource":"*" }
       ]
      }
       
    2. aws iam create-policy --policy-name lambda-boundary --policy-document file://boundary.json
  2. Attach the boundary
    1. aws iam put-role-permissions-boundary \
          --role-name OrderProcessorRole \
          --permissions-boundary arn:aws:iam::<acct>:policy/lambda-boundary
  3. Enforce automatically
    • Add a pipeline check (e.g., cfn-lint, Checkov) that fails if a new role lacks PermissionBoundary.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-permissions-boundary-check and create a similar custom rule for roles to detect drift.
  4. Maintain
    Review the boundary every quarter: remove unused Allow actions, add new ones only after peer approval, and keep the policy version history in source control.

References

  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities
  • Lambda security best practices IAM boundaries

countermeasure.name: Deploy VPC Lambda functions across multiple Availability Zones
countermeasure.desc:
For every Lambda function that runs inside a VPC, attach at least two private subnets that reside in different Availability Zones (AZs). Lambda automatically spreads function instances across all subnets you specify, so providing subnets in multiple AZs gives the function resiliency against an AZ-level failure.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet planning In the target VPC, create two or more /24 (or smaller) private subnets, each located in a distinct AZ (for example, subnet-az1a-private, subnet-az1b-private). If the function needs outbound internet access, give every AZ its own NAT gateway or egress path.
  2. Configure the function
    • Console: Configuration VPC Edit select the VPC and tick both (or all) private subnets.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
      • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
         --function-name order-processor \
         --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0a12,subnet-0b34,SecurityGroupIds=sg-0abc
  3. Security groups Attach a least-privilege security group that allows only the ports and CIDRs the function truly needs (for example, TCP 5432 to an RDS cluster SG).
  4. Guardrails Implement an AWS Config custom rule or cfn-nag check that fails a deployment when a VPC-connected Lambda lists fewer than two subnets.
  5. Validation & monitoring Use the Lambda consoles Monitoring Subnet metrics or CloudWatchs Duration metrics to confirm invocations appear from each AZ. Include a canary test that fires if an AZs invocations drop to zero.

Spreading subnets across Availability Zones ensures the function continues to invoke even if one AZor its networking componentsbecomes unavailable.

References

  • AWS Lambda resilience guidance
  • Create more than one subnet across different AZ

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Lambda env vars and code artifacts with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Safeguard every sensitive value that AWS Lambda storesenvironment variables, .zip deployment packages, container images, and event-filter criteriaby encrypting them with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of the default AWS-managed key. Using your own CMK lets you control key rotation, scope decrypt permissions tightly, and audit every use.

1 . Create or choose a CMK

aws kms create-key --description "Lambda data-at-rest CMK"
aws kms enable-key-rotation --key-id <key-id>

Limit the key policy to the Lambda service principal and the minimal set of roles that need kms:Decrypt / kms:GenerateDataKey.

2 . Encrypt environment variables

  • Console / IaC: set the KMS key ARN field (CloudFormation KmsKeyArn, Terraform kms_key_arn).
  • CLI:
    • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
          --function-name order-processor \
          --kms-key-arn arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd

Lambda now uses your CMK to encrypt Env Vars and event-filter JSON.

3 . Protect deployment artifacts

  • .zip packages in S3 store them in a bucket with SSE-KMS and the same CMK:
    • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
          --bucket lambda-artifacts-prod \
          --server-side-encryption-configuration \
          '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":
             {"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/lambda-data"}}]}'
  • Container images in ECR ensure the ECR repository uses KMS encryption with your CMK.

4 . Grant least-privilege KMS access

Add this statement (scoped to the CMK ARN) to the functions execution role:

{
 "Effect": "Allow",
 "Action": [
   "kms:Decrypt",
   "kms:GenerateDataKey*"
 ],
 "Resource": "arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd"
}

5 . Continuous assurance

  • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-env-vars-encrypted (or a custom rule) to flag functions without a CMK.
  • Create CloudWatch alarms on KMS metric NumberOfFailedDecryptRequests.
  • Rotate the CMK annually; update KmsKeyArn in templates, then disable the old key after confirming no decrypt errors.

Encrypting Lambda data with your own KMS keys gives you full custody of cryptographic material, meets stringent compliance mandates, and lets you trace every decrypt back to an invoking principal.

References

  • Encrypting environment variables and artifacts with a customer-managed KMS key
  • Using AWS KMS keys with AWS Lambda

countermeasure.name: Enforce bootstrap-aware CI/CD reviews and linting
countermeasure.desc:
To implement the security countermeasure that safeguards AWS Lambda custom runtimes by treating 'bootstrap' and Lambda runtime layers as sensitive code, follow the steps outlined below:

  1. Establish a Peer Review Process:
    • Define a policy that mandates peer reviews for any changes to files named 'bootstrap' or runtime layers containing 'bootstrap'.
    • Implement a system in your version control platform (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket) that explicitly requires an "approval" label before merging code involving these sensitive components.
    • Ensure that reviewers are experienced in security practices and familiar with Lambda runtimes.
  2. Deploy Static Code Analysis Tools:
    • Integrate static analysis tools (e.g., Checkmarx, SonarQube) into the CI/CD pipeline.
    • Configure these tools to flag and fail builds when detected risky constructs such as:
      • curl, wget, or nc
      • Any usage of bash -c
      • Unchecked or blind network egress calls
    • Introduce an allowlist mechanism where risky constructs can only bypass checks if accompanied by a written, justified reason reviewed and approved by security teams.
  3. Restrict Bootstrap Role:
    • Verify that the 'bootstrap' file solely performs runtime initialization tasks and invokes the handler or Runtime Interface Client (RIC) as designed.
    • Apply rules to forbid any embedded persistence, telemetry beacons, or additional functionality within the 'bootstrap', unless explicitly approved through the peer-review process.
    • Audit the 'bootstrap' code periodically to ensure compliance with these restrictions.
  4. Enforce Pipeline-Only Deployment:
    • Block any direct uploads of Lambda runtime layers or the 'bootstrap' file via the AWS Management Console.
    • Configure permissions so that developers can only deploy changes through a CI/CD pipeline that enforces defined security checks.
    • Apply IAM policies to prevent unauthorized access to runtime layer modification workflows.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Official Documentation
  • AWS CodePipeline Documentation
  • AWS Security Blog

countermeasure.name: Enforce code-signed Lambda deployments with AWS Signer
countermeasure.desc:
Guarantee that only vetted code reaches production by pairing AWS Signer with a Lambda Code Signing Configuration (CSC): every deployment package must be signed with your approved signing profile before Lambda accepts it.

  1. Create a signing profile
    1. aws signer put-signing-profile \
       --profile-name prod-lambda-code \
       --platform-id AWSLambda-SHA384-ECDSA
  2. Store the profile ARN in your CI/CD secrets.
  3. Integrate signing into the pipeline
    • Package the ZIP or container image, then call aws signer start-signing-job (ZIP) or ECR image signing (container).
    • Fail the build if the signing job status isnt Succeeded.
  4. Define a Code Signing Configuration
    1. aws lambda create-code-signing-config \
       --allowed-publishers SigningProfileVersionArns=arn:aws:signer::profile/prod-lambda-code/* \
       --code-signing-policies UntrustedArtifactOnDeployment=Enforce
  5. Enforce blocks any unsigned or differently-signed artifact.
  6. Attach the CSC to functions
    1. aws lambda update-function-code-signing-config \
       --function-name orders-handler \
       --code-signing-config-arn arn:aws:lambda::code-signing-config:csc-abc123
  7. Include this step in all CloudFormation/Terraform modules so drift is impossible.
  8. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Enable the AWS Config rule lambda-function-code-signing-config-enabled to detect functions without a CSC.
    • Use EventBridge to alert when a deployment fails due to CodeSigningError, signalling a bypass attempt or pipeline mis-sign.
  9. Key hygiene
    • Rotate the Signer KMS key annually; update the signing profile to the new key version.
    • Restrict signer:StartSigningJob permission to the build role; deny it in production accounts via SCPs.

By requiring AWS-signed packages and enforcing CSCs, you shut the door on tampered artifacts, typo-squatted libraries, and shadow deployments.

References

  • Code signing for AWS Lambda
  • AWS Signer Developer Guide

countermeasure.name: Enforce tagging standards on Lambda functions
countermeasure.desc:
Every Lambda function must carry a complete, standardized tag set for example Environment, Owner, CostCenter, and Compliance so that security, cost-allocation, and automation workflows can rely on consistent metadata.

How to implement

  1. Define the mandatory keys in a central document (e.g., tagging-standard.md) and publish it to your IaC repository.
  2. Validate in the pipeline
    • Add a build step (cfn-lint/Checkov/GitHub Action, etc.) that fails if the template or aws lambda create-function command omits any required tag.
  3. Enforce at runtime with AWS Config
    • Enable the managed rule required-tags or deploy a custom rule that checks the AWS::Lambda::Function resource type and your mandatory tag list.
    • Configure the rule for continuous evaluation and send non-compliant findings to Security Hub or an SNS topic that opens a ticket.
  4. Auto-remediate or quarantine
    • Attach an EventBridge rule to run an SSM Automation or Lambda fixer script that adds missing tagsor, in strict environments, disables the function until tags are corrected.
  5. Review quarterly
    • Spot-check tag accuracy (e.g., does the Owner tag still map to an active identity?) and update the standard when new reporting requirements appear.

Automated tagging enforcement guarantees that every Lambda function can be located, costed, and governed, while eliminating drift caused by manual provisioning.

References

  • Tagging Lambda functions
  • AWS Config rule required-tags

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2+ with perfect-forward-secrecy for all Lambda traffic
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure every network path that carries AWS Lambda control-plane or data-plane trafficCLI / SDK calls to the Lambda API, Function URLs, ALB/API Gateway invokes, VPC egress, and third-party integrationsnegotiates TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3 using PFS cipher suites (ECDHE or DHE). Disable legacy SSL/TLS versions and static-key ciphers to eliminate downgrade and session-key compromise risks.

Implementation guidance

  1. Runtime & library hardening
    • Use current AWS SDKs, AWS CLI v2, and OS packages (OpenSSL 1.1.1, Java 8 u181, .NET 4.6) that default to TLS 1.2+.
    • In container images or AMIs set MinProtocol = TLSv1.2 and remove *_RSA_* suites from the cipher list.
  2. Outbound Lambda networking
    • When the function runs in a VPC, allow only TCP 443 to interface endpoints (S3, STS, Secrets Manager, etc.). Block port 80 in security groups and route tables.
    • For external calls, pin the destination to https:// URIs and verify certificates (e.g., with Python requests.verify=True).
  3. Inbound invoke paths
    • Function URLs: set AuthType=AWS_IAM or another auth method; TLS is auto-enforced by AWS but add a WAF rule that blocks any request with the X-Forwarded-Proto != https.
    • API Gateway / ALB: enable TLS 1.2 minimum on the custom domain or listener policy; prefer ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06.
    • For IoT or custom MQTT, use certificates that advertise only TLS 1.2/1.3 and EC cipher suites.
  4. Central guardrails
    • Attach an SCP that denies lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl or execute-api:Invoke when aws:SecureTransport is false.
    • Deploy AWS Config rules or cfn-nag checks that fail if an ALB listener policy includes TLS 1.0/1.1 or if a VPC security group permits port 80 egress.
  5. Continuous verification
    • Add a CI test that attempts openssl s_client -connect lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com:443 -tls1_1 and expect failure; succeed with -tls1_2.
    • Scan AMIs and containers monthly with Inspector or OpenSCAP for outdated OpenSSL/LibreSSL versions.
  6. Incident response & patching
    • Subscribe to AWS Security Bulletins; redeploy all Lambda runtime layers when critical TLS CVEs are announced.
    • Rotate any function URL or API Gateway custom certificates that use deprecated algorithms (RSA-1024, SHA-1).

Following this control guarantees strong, modern encryption end-to-end, satisfying compliance frameworks and protecting Lambda workloads against passive interception and forward-decryption attacks.

References

  • TLS 1.2 to become the minimum for all AWS service endpoints
  • Best practices for AWS Lambda security
